entry.title: Informatics Ignite Talks August 2013
entry.content:
After a very successful first edition of our ignite talks in December 2012, we did it again last week.

This time around we had nine five minute talks. In these talks we presented our latest projects, we covered the challenges faced in the development of IT projects, and we introduced ways to overcome the challenges and improve our processes.

Craig Mills opened the session and talked about improving the quality of the tools developed in our sector and how we should be passionate about what we do.

Decio Battaglia did the first project related talk. He talked about a URL shortener that allows us to share our work and track who is looking at it.

Next up was Tim Wilkinson who talked about the challenges of estimation and how we go about doing it at UNEP-WCMC with agile planning.

The National Reporting Toolkit is one of our most recent projects and James Cox introduced it to our colleagues at UNEP-WCMC.

In our day to day work at UNEP-WCMC we always try to "change for the better", to Kaizen. In her talk Agnieszka Figiel explained how we can change for the better by taking advantage of slack time.

In December 2012 I talked about the ISIP project. In the meantime the project has been renamed Species+ and it's getting closer to completion. In my talk I introduced the Species+ Website one of the outputs of this project.

One other project that we have started developing in 2012 and we aim at using in different future applications is named My Polygon and allows users to draw polygons on top of web maps and obtain details about the underlying layers. Miguel Torres our Geospatial Developer gave a talk about this project and the how we made sure that we can provide the users with accurate results in a very short amount of time.

Blanca Tortajada Perez, our designer in Informatics talked about the importance of content strategy, and its central role in the development of our projects.

Anyone that develops software knows that bugs are inevitable. Nevertheless there are ways to try to avoid them or as a last resort to find them early on and fix them. Adam Mulligan closed these Ignite sessions talking about different types of bugs and how we handle them at UNEP-WCMC.

We really enjoyed preparing these talks, and we believe that it is very important to show the work that we are developing and how we aim to improve our processes. We are more than happy to answer any questions that you might have, so feel free to leave a comment or send us an email.

We hope to be back in the future with another edition of WCMC's Informatics Ignite Talks!

entry.title: Informatics Ignite Talks 2012
entry.content:
On the 11th of December 2012 our team prepared a series of Ignite Talks to show our colleagues at UNEP-WCMC the work that we are doing and how we go about doing it.

The session started with a talk by our Head of Programme, Craig Mills. He talked about our team and work in 2012.

Next up was Agnieszka Figiel one of our Ruby on Rails Developers. Agnieszka explained how we go about delivering excelence.

I followed Agnieszka and talked about one of the big projects that we started in 2012, the Integrated Species Information Platform. A project that is focused in the redevelopment of the species databases maitained at UNEP-WCMC, and the creation of new bespoke public facing interfaces to explore that data.

James Cox talked about the A.P.E.S. Dashboard. This web application was developed in BackboneJS in early 2012 and is a way for Governments to decide where to invest their money to protect great apes.

DÃ©cio Ferreira talked about the Voluntary REDD+ Database. A tool to provide information to the global community on REDD+ financing, actions and results, providing the ability to search, summarise and visualize data. (Unfortunately his talk is not yet available online).

The last talk of this Ignite Session was done by Tim Wilkinson. Tim talked about the Abu Dhabi Blue Carbon project, our first iPad App. This application allows scientist to measure the carbon sequestered by coastal habitats like mangroves, seagrass, and others. Data can be collected off-line and then syncronised back into a web server.

After Tim's talk Craig Mills has closed the session with a quick glimpse into the year of 2013.

Ignite Talks: each of our talks lasted for 5 minutes and consisted of 20 slides that transitioned automatically after 15 seconds.
